Topic.Title: Newz headlline readz: "Authors Guild head blasts Amazon buy of Goodreads"

Message.Msg: "He will undercut what authorz make by low balling them." Goodreads is just a place where readers discuss books. It has nothing to do with what authors make or don't make. "Bezos hasnt disclosed what he paid" News reports say it is about $160 million with some possible bonuses attached depending on whether the site meets certain targets putting the upper range around $200 million in total. "The web site haz 16 million 'subs'" So Amazon breaks even at about $10 per sub. Sounds like a pretty good deal. "but it will decline and errode, and will never make any money" Ha! Where will 16 million people go? Amazon already owns all the competing sites. People don't tend to move around that much, they tend to stay put in the communities they've gotten used to. Only some ignorant short would think that the goal is for the site to generate its own profits. Everyone else understands that these things merely generate more sales of books and that Amazon will make $billions in book profits in upcoming years.

Sybil callz it the TECH FACTOR. Here's how it works: Now sybs had a hunch for yearz that optionz on a grand scale are going to be one of several major components leading the boom / bust cycle that we are in. Tech haz been a BIG trader of 'quality' DITM , 6 month, 9 month and leap optionz all the way through this cycle; just Waiting for pig stox drop on puts and barking dogz to get up and run on callz..... Ok let sybs get to the point: When tech capitulates on optionz and sybs dumps scam bear etfs that ise optionz in disgust - that will be an indication of the top... Or if tech and sybs dont capitulate only to find that optionz contracts and etfs side bets will be liquidated to 0 without being honored due to 'black swan' market conditionz - that will be a sign that the crash iz in full effect.

Topic.Title: Sybil haz an amazing prediction for todayz action

Message.Msg: Amazon bears the gas cost because it pays for the last mile. TGT and WMT do not. Further, consumers have plenty of TGT and WMT stores on existing travel routes. Incremental/marginal cost is limited. Amazon's economic model was well suited to high interest rates and low gas costs. We have the opposite and will continue to into the future. You've got the stock price argument (for now). But, on fundies you have nothing.

Topic.Title: Sybil haz an amazing prediction for todayz action

Message.Msg: Except if it were true that incremental costs were limited TGT and WMT would not have been threatened by selling Kindles in their stores. Consumers have come to realize they bear a lot of TGT and WMT's last mile and with higher gas prices this becomes more an more transparent to them. These stores aren't really well located. To save on cost they are purposely located near the edges of cities, not centrally. You must live in a low rent area if you think this. And what ever advantage you described that they had in this, with the change in tax law, Amazon has now moved much closer to the consumer, and so their last mile has just gotten a whole lot shorter an cheaper to fulfill from. For now? I've always had stock price argument since you got here at $180. I'll have it at over $300 when your last crushing margin calls come as well.

Topic.Title: Sybil haz an amazing prediction for todayz action

Message.Msg: "The last mile just got a lot shorter" -- your intellect is truly dizzying... Amazon's moves to date do nothing to affect the last mile. It has greatly increased aggregate inventory, reduced inventory turns and reduced ROIC, but it has been unable to offset the rising shipping cost. (All, look at gross shipping as a percent of net sales... increasing. Only internal revenue transfers from Prime in 2012 reduced net and even then, it is higher than net shipping as a % of net sales in 2010, even after significant expansion of facilities... Nem doesn't like the let the facts get in the way of his story (he would fit well on the Amazon sell side). BTW, you must live on another planet claiming Target only locates outside major population centers and are inconvenient... Google Target IN Chicago... or NYC. Or choose your city. Moron. Unless a household is going to buy everything online (not so practical or cost effective), they will still travel to stores as part of life. Few evaluate the fuel cost and even those that do will simply make fewer, larger trips...
